description: I have used this on linux mint , ubuntu , kubuntu , and other operating systems. works fine for me. Has a few issues though. after playing a game or using the interface /controller config / and other settings. Sometimes you have to close it after playing or configering or program will not close. Would have gave 5 stars if not for issue. So when you are done with one game , close and restart program. Do the same after each configering. Or you will have to kill the process or restart computer. Overall I do like it. Hope this helps others.

I'm guessing those that are having problems with this emulator is due to not having bios. You're going to need to load your own bios in Home/.pcsxr/bios, preferably scph5501.bin (for US and this one is the most popular bios). PCSXR is a competent emulator at least for me.

summary: This Is a broken install of pcsxr For ubuntu needs updated

description:
Works perfectly once you do some adjustments.
Note: Do CTRL+H to show hidden folders.
1) Download a PSX BIOS file (SCPH1001.bin) and place it in the BIOS folder located at '~/.pcsxr'
2) Using a text editor, edit the file pcsx.cfg located at '~/.pcsx/pcsx.cfg' like this
==> change 'Cpu = 0' to 'Cpu = 1'
3) Run the emulator, go to Configuration and select the BIOS.
4) If the emulator crashes as soon as you load a iso, go to Configuration and change the Graphics driver to OpenGL.
Hope this helps, have fun

Requires you change the pcsx.cfg file from CPU = 0 to CPU = 1 or it'll crash when you try to run a game

Emulation works well once you get (and set) the bios file for it, otherwise it'll crash when you try to run a game

Setting up a controller won't work if you have two controllers plugged in at the same time.
Not normally a problem, (just take one out and configure them one after the other) but my playstation to USB converter has two ports, so it registers as two controllers regardless of how many controllers are plugged in.
To get around this i had to follow a guide here: 
https://askubuntu.com/questions/1173751/how-can-make-the-controler-configuration-window-show-in-pcsxr

However, your mileage may vary:
The guide didn't work ultimately, it actually broke the controller plugin (it didn't show up on the plugin list any more), but once i completed the guide and then reinstalled PCSXR, the controllers just seemed to work by magic. So, i guess i just got lucky?

The emulation works well though, pretty smooth from as far as i could tell, and there's lots of fiddly options as is standard for emulators. Good luck!
summary: Works, but not before you do some tweaking

description: Works with Ubuntu Studio but upon Dec 2019 update, control config isn't showing.

Works perfectly once you do some adjustments.
Note: Do CTRL+H to show hidden folders.
1) Download a PSX BIOS file (SCPH1001.bin) and place it in the BIOS folder located at '~/.pcsxr'
2) Using a text editor, edit the file pcsx.cfg located at '~/.pcsx/pcsx.cfg' like this
==> change 'Cpu = 0' to 'Cpu = 1'
3) Run the emulator, go to Configuration and select the BIOS.
4) If the emulator crashes as soon as you load a iso, go to Configuration and change the Graphics driver to OpenGL.
Hope this helps, have fun
Great support in games, and fast. Very cool emulator

It emulates heavy 3d PS1 games with good fps. There are lots of options, you can use widescreen hack (bad idea for any 2d only game, but good on most 3d games and the ones where the map is 3d and characters are 2d), game fixes, etc. 
If you just install it and try to play right away it probably won't work. After starting it once, close it, then go to ~/.pcsxr and open the .cfg file. Go down to the line where you see "Cpu = 0", change it to 1 and save. It is also a good idea to put the scph1001.bin bios inside the Bios folder at the same ~/.pcsxr location. Also, go to graphics settings (the monitor icon), then click the "Textures" tab and set the VRam size to 1024 (if your GPU have at least 1gb of vram, it probably have unless it is too old). To keep PS1 aspect ratio you need to check the two options "Keep psx aspect ratio" and "Force 4:3 aspect ratio", at least on my system when I check only one of these two option the trick doesn't work. Once all of this is done you are ready to go. 
4 stars since it doesn't work out of the box.

Funciona bastante bien y es muy facil de configurar lo basico para que funcione, ademas que tiene muchas herramientas, lo que le proporciona bastantes posibilidades.

Aun asi, hay pequeños detalles derivados de los cambios entre la ventana del emulador y las de otras aplicaciones (p.e. en el medievil quedaba "pulsado" algun boton pero el teclado no esta activo en el emulador, entonces tienes que darle para que se active y entonces recuperas el control)

Vayan a su carpeta de usuario, habiliten para ver carpetas ocultas y veran una carpeta llamada .pcsxr
Entran a esa carpeta y hay un archivo de texto llamado pcsxr.cfg al que deberan cambiar bien abajo donde dice CPU = 0 ese numero cero cambiarlo por 1 y deberia quedar CPU = 1
Entonces guardan la modificacion presionando Ctrl+S y entonces ahora si funciona usar las imagenes ISO que antes daban error. No se entiende porque no esta habilitado por defecto esa opcion, la mayoria no entiende ni nada de hacer estas cosas.
